fields.Project Description: PDC’s National Disaster Preparedness Baseline Assessment is more than an assessment. It is a long-term program designed to help countries evaluate risk and disaster management capacity and apply these insights to early warning, disaster preparedness, policy and planning, sustainable development, and resilience-building initiatives. The national baseline assessment is the only U.S. program recognized by the United Nations to assist countries in operationalizing the goals of the Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction. It provides an evidence-based foundation for actions to be taken and investments to be made in achieving long-term resilience and strengthening national disaster preparedness.

Managed by the Humanitarian OpenStreetMap Team, the Field Mapping Tasking Manager (FMTM) coordinates mapping campaigns in crisis zones through volunteer contributions. It organizes tasks, quality controls labeling, and integrates open geospatial datasets into humanitarian operational platforms.
WHO offers globally standardized health data through its GHO portal, providing indicators on disease, mortality, and service coverage via APIs and downloadable data under open access licenses.

A new generation risk data initiative is shining a light on where climate, conflict, and displacement risks collide across sub-Saharan Africa, North Africa, and the Middle East (MENA). By integrating these drivers into one analytical stream, it delivers actionable insights tailored to conflict-affected and climate-vulnerable populations, filling critical gaps and enabling anticipatory action. Led by the Red Cross Red Crescent Climate Centre, together with the Netherlands Red Cross’ 510 Initiative and the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC), the risk data supports more informed and anticipatory decision-making across the humanitarian system.

Flowminder strengthens the capacity of governments, UN agencies, mobile operators, private companies, and NGOs to maximize the benefits of new analytic techniques and data sources. Through expertise in geospatial and mobile operator data analytics, Flowminder collaborates with in-country partners to enhance data use among decision makers and to develop sustainable, long-lasting solutions.

This platform curates and disseminates datasets, reports, and indicators related to fragility, conflict, and violence. It supports development and humanitarian actors by improving access to evidence on conflict dynamics and institutional resilience.

The forecast platform provides predictive models of displacement risk based on conflict, climate, and governance indicators. It offers downloadable datasets and visual forecasts to support anticipatory humanitarian programming.

QGIS is a free, open-source geographic information system (GIS) application used worldwide for mapping, spatial analysis, and geostatistical modeling. It supports both raster and vector data and is widely adopted by humanitarian, environmental, and development actors.
The Conflict Data Dashboard displays all recorded security incidents, meaning it shows all ‘Security incidents’ as defined above that have been recorded by INSO, not only those that affected NGOs.
It is an enhanced interactive interface that displays a map of all the countries where the IPC operates and provides the option to download population data.

UNFPA, the United Nations Population Fund, works globally to ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health, prevent and respond to gender-based violence, collect and use population data, and promote gender equality and the empowerment of women and youth across the humanitarian and development continuum.

The Global Health Observatory (GHO) is the World Health Organization’s flagship global portal for health statistics and indicators. It provides datasets across themes such as mortality, disease burden, and service coverage, with API access available for researchers and policymakers.

Provides standardized global administrative boundary datasets, essential for geospatial analysis and mapping. Open-access and regularly updated, these boundaries support humanitarian planning, statistical frameworks, and international data interoperability.
An online learning platform that offers training, MOOCs, and webinars focused on statistical capacity building and data system strengthening to support evidence-based policymaking.

IDMC’s Internal Displacement Updates (IDU) offer preliminary, timely, and detailed insights into new displacement events, reflecting ongoing daily monitoring efforts. This event-based dataset provides initial snapshots of displacement trends, which may later be refined and consolidated in the Global Internal Displacement Database (GIDD). It is important to note that these figures do not undergo the same level of quality control as the GIDD data, as the IDU data reflects timely updates that are subject to change as more information becomes available following a displacement event.

This dataset contains dekadal rainfall indicators computed from Climate Hazards Group InfraRed Precipitation satellite imagery combined with in situ station data (CHIRPS) version 2. The data is aggregated by subnational administrative units for the asset Rainfall Indicators.
UNHCR’s MSNA platform collects standardized multi-sector needs data in refugee settings, covering shelter, protection, livelihood, and health metrics to guide program planning and coordination.

The INFORM Severity Index is an improved method for analyzing the severity of humanitarian crises on a global scale. It aims to enhance the management of humanitarian crises by providing decision-makers with a comparable and reliable summary of information regarding the severity of such crises. This information is updated monthly and is applicable worldwide. Since 2016, INFORM partners have been developing the INFORM Severity Index to complement the widely used INFORM Risk Index.

CrisisWatch is a global conflict tracker and early warning tool designed to help prevent deadly violence. It keeps decision-makers up-to-date with developments in over 70 conflicts and crises every month, identifying trends and alerting them to risks of escalation and opportunities to advance peace. In addition, CrisisWatch monitors over 50 situations through “standby monitoring” to provide timely information if developments indicate a drift toward violence or instability. Entries dating back to 2003 offer easily searchable conflict histories for the asset CrisisWatch.

WWIS is a centralized WMO platform that provides authoritative city-level weather forecasts and climate summaries, sourced from national meteorological and hydrological services. It supports risk awareness and decision-making by offering free, real-time access to standardized global weather data.

fields.Project/Product Name: WASH Knowledge, Attitudes and Practices (KAP) Survey
fields.Project Description: Routine monitoring of the WASH services provided is paramount for quality assurance, ensuring the set standards are met within stipulated timelines, challenges are identified in time, and solutions are sought. UNHCR (Cox’s Bazar Field Office) conducted the third round of its WASH Knowledge, Attitude and Practice (KAP) survey from 15th to 23rd November 2023 in UNHCR’s area of operation in Kutupalong and Teknaf. Five WASH partners implemented the survey.

GUARD delivers rapid vulnerability analysis for at-risk populations in sudden-onset disasters through an automated web tool and open-source event dataset. This drives real-time insights, equitable resource allocation, and inclusive, evidence-based response plans. CRAF’d finances the tool and dataset development, rigorous validation, and integration into national disaster management frameworks f

The Climate Action Navigator delivers climate action indicators tailored to specific cities. Using a framework of high-resolution spatial indicators, it provides actionable insights through data, maps, and reports co-developed with our partners. The dashboard integrates multiple data sources, including OpenStreetMap (OSM), openrouteservice (ORS), satellite imagery, and scientific research, ensuring comprehensive and reliable insights for decision-makers.

Data Insights for Social & Humanitarian Action, also known as DISHA, is a multi-partner initiative led by UN Global Pulse, the Secretary-General’s Innovation Lab. The initiative aims to accelerate ethical and responsible access to data and artificial intelligence (AI) solutions in order to unlock social impact at scale.

The UN General Assembly established the UN Register of Conventional Arms (UNROCA) in 1991 through resolution 46/36 L to promote transparency in armaments. Through the UNROCA instrument, Member States are requested, on an annual basis, to report their international transfers of seven categories of major conventional arms, as well as small arms and light weapons. They may also provide additional background information, such as data on military holdings and procurement through national production. To date, 175 Member States have reported to the UNROCA instrument at least once. In light of relatively consistent reporting by the world’s largest arms exporters, it is estimated that the Register captures around 90 percent of the volume of the global arms trade.
GANNET is a real-time, end-to-end Generative AI platform that combines near real-time assistance, analytics, and monitoring features for humanitarian data collaboration and effective decision-making.
WorldPop develops peer-reviewed research and methodologies for constructing open and high-resolution geospatial data on population distributions, demographics, and dynamics.

HungerMapLIVE is the World Food Programme (WFP)’s global hunger monitoring system. It combines key metrics from various data sources—such as food security information, weather, population size, conflict, hazards, nutrition information, and macro-economic data—to help assess, monitor, and predict the magnitude and severity of hunger in near real-time. The resulting analysis is displayed on an interactive map that enables WFP staff, key decision makers, and the broader humanitarian community to make more informed and timely decisions relating to food security.

GDHO is a global compendium of organisations that provide aid in humanitarian crises. The database includes basic organisational and operational information on these humanitarian providers, which include international non-governmental organisations (grouped by federation), national NGOs that deliver aid within their own borders, UN humanitarian agencies, and the International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement.

The Service Provision Assessment (SPA) is a health facility survey designed to collect information on service availability and Quality of Care (QoC) measures within a country’s health system. The SPA addresses the urgent need for actionable monitoring data in participating countries. It assesses the availability and quality of care for a wide range of services, with a particular focus on antenatal care (ANC), family planning (FP), maternity care, and sick child services. Quality of Care measures are evaluated across two dimensions: structural quality, which includes physical and human resources, and process quality, which encompasses the provision of care and the experience of care.

Trigger models are employed to establish danger levels that activate humanitarian anticipatory Early Action Protocols (EAPs). These models are developed using the Impact-Based Forecasting (IBF) methodology. Models have been built to trigger EAPs for hazards such as typhoon, flood, dzud, drought, and dengue. This approach supports the Enhanced Vulnerability and Capacity Assessment (EVCA) by providing a systematic and evidence-based process for determining when early action should be taken in response to specific risks.

The IPC Population Tracking Tool is an online platform that provides public access to population data from more than 30 different countries. It enables users to download resource data for offline IPC analyses dating back to 2017. All national population figures are derived from official country population estimates, while IPC estimates are those published in country IPC reports.

Afrobarometer is a pan-African public-opinion research network that provides survey insights into democracy, governance, and economic conditions. Survey microdata and analysis tools are publicly available through an open-access portal.

When major emergencies occur, MapAction provides surge support to partners at short notice, enabling them to make sense of chaotic, dangerous, and rapidly evolving situations and to coordinate the most effective response. MapAction operates both in-country and remotely. The organization’s well-rehearsed deployment model ensures that mapping professionals can be on the scene within 24-48 hours of a disaster striking. Even before arriving in-country, they begin collecting data and information that will be crucial in helping to coordinate the global response and ensure that aid reaches those who need it most.

As part of IDMC's investment in more systematic monitoring of national and global efforts to reduce the risk, scale, and negative impacts of internal displacement, the Global Repository of Good Practices provides a platform to compile, share, and evaluate policies and programmatic approaches to support better solutions for internally displaced people worldwide.

Common Operational Datasets (CODs) are authoritative reference datasets utilized by humanitarian organizations to support response efforts and inform decision-making. They offer a consistent and standardized data framework that enables all actors involved in a crisis to coordinate effectively.

DisasterAWARE is a global platform that provides real-time hazard alerts, dashboards, and geospatial tools to support disaster preparedness and early warning. The platform integrates predictive models and hazard tracking using data from global datasets, enabling comprehensive monitoring and response to potential disasters.

OCHA’s Common Operational Data Administrative Boundaries (COD‑AB) is a curated, harmonized global dataset aligned with OCHA’s COD standard. It is designed to support mapping, analysis, and coordination in humanitarian operations.

The Rapid Assessment Data project accelerates the reporting of conflict-related violence in fragile settings by automating data gathering from open and established sources and integrating Machine Learning (ML) driven analysis. The project’s impacts include enhanced risk assessment, more targeted interventions, and the empowerment of at-risk populations to advocate for protective measures.

Since the mid-1990s, more than 120 countries have conducted one or more Multiple Indicator Cluster Surveys (MICS), generating data on key indicators related to the well-being of children and supporting the development of policies aimed at improving their lives.

UNOSAT provides geospatial analysis and satellite imagery to support disaster response, humanitarian aid, and sustainable development. It offers on-demand and open-access mapping services through interactive portals, data hubs, and geospatial APIs.

fields.Project/Product Name: Global Humanitarian Operational Presence Who, What, Where (3W) Portal
fields.Project Description: The 3W data is sourced from OCHA country and regional offices around the world and compiled by the Field Information Services (FIS) Section of OCHA. The data are as provided, and organization names and acronyms are not standardized. The frequency of 3W data collection varies across offices, and the compiled database includes what is available up to the date of publishing. This information supports the asset Global Humanitarian Operational Presence Who, What, Where (3W) Portal.

Latinobarómetro is an annual public opinion survey that involves approximately 20,000 interviews in 18 Latin American countries, representing more than 600 million inhabitants. Some of the most relevant sections of the Latinobarómetro for freedom of expression and media development are "Democracy" and "Media, Internet and Social Media." Key topics include activities people like to do on the internet, perceptions of the use of private data for commercial purposes, and preferred social media platforms. The survey data is provided by Corporación Latinobarómetro.

The ohsome dashboard enables users to analyze OSM’s full-history data without programming skills. It generates accurate statistics and plots them directly in the dashboard, allowing for customizable filtering and grouping of tags and types across any region or time period. The ohsome quality API (OQAPI) provides access to OSM data quality information for specific regions and use-cases which might benefit i.e. humanitarian organizations and public administration.

This Observatory provides updated information on the killing of journalists since 1993 and on the judicial status of condemned cases since 2006. It also provides public access to country responses to UNESCO's requests for information into the judicial status of ongoing and unresolved cases. You may browse the full list of killed journalists and search for visual statistics and data.

Each year, disasters around the world kill nearly 100,000 people and affect or displace 200 million more. Many of the locations where these disasters occur are not represented on open and accessible maps, leaving first responders without the critical information needed to make informed decisions about relief efforts. Missing Maps is an open, collaborative project designed to map areas where humanitarian organizations are working to address the needs of people living at risk of disasters and crises. This initiative enables volunteers to contribute to mapping efforts, helping to ensure that vulnerable communities are visible and better supported during emergencies.

The Population Data Portal serves as UNFPA’s comprehensive data source and tracker for population and development statistics. It brings together the latest data on topics such as sexual and reproductive health and rights, family planning, maternal health, and gender-based violence, collected from a variety of sources. The portal provides users with reliable, up-to-date information to support research, policy-making, and program development in the field of population and development.

Openrouteservice is an open-source platform leveraging OpenStreetMap data to provide advanced mobility and accessibility analysis. Surrounding the core engine is a vibrant ecosystem of services and tools, enabling seamless integration into diverse projects. We are committed to transparency, making our tools and research freely accessible. Our interactive map client highlights the platform’s capabilities and is available for anyone to explore.

The International Organization for Migration’s Global Data Institute introduces PRIMARI, an ambitious initiative designed to enhance understanding of global mobility by consolidating sub-national displacement data with migration insights. This project aims to create a composite dataset covering up to 60 countries, utilizing the extensive data resources of the Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM). PRIMARI is distinguished by its dedication to integrating diverse data streams into a single, accessible, and actionable dataset, supported by a comprehensive metadata repository to ensure data transparency and integrity.

Humanitarian Geoanalytics integrates spatial data analysis, mapping, and field-based research to support humanitarian operations. It focuses on conflict dynamics, displacement, and vulnerability assessments using geospatial methods.

fields.Project/Product Name: Global Disaster Alert and Coordination System (GDACS)
fields.Project Description: The Global Disaster Alert and Coordination System (GDACS) is a cooperation framework between the United Nations, the European Commission, and disaster managers worldwide. Its purpose is to improve alerts, facilitate information exchange, and enhance coordination during the initial phase following major sudden-onset disasters.

fields.Project/Product Name: Platform for Real-Time Impact and Situation Monitoring (PRISM)
fields.Project Description: PRISM is a climate risk monitoring system that integrates geospatial data on hazards such as droughts, floods, tropical storms, and earthquakes, along with socioeconomic vulnerability information. It provides decision-makers with interactive maps and charts to support disaster risk reduction and social assistance programs for the asset Platform for Real-Time Impact and Situation Monitoring (PRISM).

HOT is an international team dedicated to humanitarian action and community development through open mapping. The team collaborates to provide map data that revolutionizes disaster management, reduces risks, and contributes to the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals.

ACLED is a widely used conflict dataset that tracks the locations, dates, actors, and types of political violence and protest events across the world. Updated weekly, it covers over 150 countries and includes data on battles, riots, strategic developments, and civilian targeting. ACLED’s open-access data and analytical tools are used by policymakers, researchers, and humanitarian organizations to monitor conflict dynamics, assess risk, and support early warning systems and humanitarian planning.

The Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM) gathers and analyzes data to disseminate critical, multi-layered information on the mobility, vulnerabilities, and needs of displaced and mobile populations. This enables decision makers and responders to provide these populations with better, context-specific assistance.

The Violence & Impacts Early-Warning System (VIEWS) is an academic research consortium and conflict prediction system jointly led by Uppsala University and the Peace Research Institute Oslo. The VIEWS consortium brings together a suite of interrelated projects dedicated to exploring state-of-the-art approaches for studying and predicting the risk of violent conflicts and their impacts on society and human development.

MapSwipe coordinates volunteer mapping of satellite imagery to create open building and infrastructure datasets in underserved areas. It supports crisis mapping, response planning, and humanitarian targeting.

fields.Project/Product Name: Copernicus Emergency Management Service Annual Conference
fields.Project Description: The Copernicus Emergency Management Service Annual Conference is a key event that brings together experts, stakeholders, and decision-makers from across Europe and beyond. The conference provides a platform for sharing knowledge, discussing best practices, and exploring the latest developments in emergency management. Participants engage in presentations, panel discussions, and interactive sessions focused on the use of Copernicus data and services in disaster risk reduction, preparedness, response, and recovery. The event highlights the impact of Copernicus Emergency Management Service products and fosters collaboration among the emergency management community, policy makers, and scientific experts.

The Signal Program explores how emerging technologies—such as remote sensing and data analytics—can support protection in humanitarian emergencies. It develops tools, ethical frameworks, and applied research for crisis contexts.

Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S) provides authoritative, open-access climate data and tools, including forecasts, historical datasets, and impact indicators. Managed by ECMWF, it supports risk analysis, adaptation planning, and policy development globally.

Data2X is a global partnership dedicated to advancing gender-responsive data systems. The organization develops research, advocacy, and tools to enhance data on women and girls, including initiatives focused on capacity strengthening and the provision of innovation grants.

fields.Project/Product Name: Kente Threads: Weaving leadership from displacement data
fields.Project Description: Kente Threads is a feminist initiative that reimagines humanitarian action by centering refugee women’s resilience and lived experiences.

The UNHCR Global Data Service (GDS) serves as a central hub for data and statistics on refugees, asylum-seekers, internally displaced persons (IDPs), and stateless individuals. It supports evidence-based decision-making, policy development, and humanitarian operations by providing access to a wide range of data tools and resources.

IMPACT’s PANDA initiative aims to improve the effectiveness, efficiency, and efficacy of humanitarian and development interventions. PANDA supports the entire humanitarian programme cycle, including programme design, assessments, baselines, monitoring, and evaluation.

fields.Project/Product Name: World Bank Living Standards Measurement Study (LSMS)
fields.Project Description: The World Bank Living Standards Measurement Study (LSMS) is the World Bank’s flagship household survey initiative that provides high-quality, nationally representative panel data for analyzing poverty, inequality, and livelihoods. Datasets are downloadable through the World Bank Microdata Library and are used to support data-driven policymaking.

fields.Project/Product Name: The State of the World’s Children Report
fields.Project Description: Published annually by UNICEF, The State of the World’s Children report is a flagship global publication that presents comprehensive data and analysis on issues affecting children’s well-being. Each edition focuses on a specific theme—such as nutrition, mental health, or education—and includes rigorous data from household surveys, administrative sources, and UNICEF’s global monitoring systems. The report serves as a key advocacy and programming resource for policymakers and humanitarian actors, offering evidence-based recommendations grounded in global and regional trends.

WorldPop is an interdisciplinary applied research group that focuses on supporting the improvement of the spatial demographic evidence base and the use of these data for health and development applications, including addressing the Sustainable Development Goals. The group’s mission is to enable decision makers to harness the power of spatial demographic data through high quality applied research, with the vision of a world where everyone, everywhere is counted in decision making.

The Water Point Data Exchange (WPDx) platform is a global open data system that compiles and standardizes information on water point locations and characteristics from multiple countries. Hosted by the Global Water Challenge, it provides a critical repository for improving water service delivery by offering insights into functionality, service levels, and infrastructure gaps. WPDx data has been used by governments, NGOs, and development partners to enhance resource allocation, plan maintenance, and track progress toward water access goals, contributing to SDG 6.
The ACLED Conflict Alert System (CAST) is a conflict forecasting visualization platform designed to predict political violence events up to six months in the future for every country in the world.

CORE is the latest data-driven initiative by Humanitarian Outcomes to provide quantifiable measures on the size of the humanitarian sector as well as its capacity and reach in crisis-affected countries.

Insecurity Insight examines threats facing people living and working in dangerous environments. The organization uses innovative data collection and analysis methods to generate insights relevant for aid workers, aid agencies, and those concerned with the protection of health workers, educators, internally displaced persons (IDPs), and refugees. The aim is to empower those who deliver vital services and to give a voice to those affected by insecurity.

In the daily whirlwind, the data avalanche generated is often underestimated. However, there is a significant opportunity in standardizing and organizing this information. Doing so unlocks valuable lessons from the past, enhances efficiency, and supports informed, strategic decision-making.

INFORM Climate Change Risk Index is an upgrade of the INFORM Risk Index as it includes climate and socio-economic projections. It provides quantified estimates of the impacts of climate change on the future risk of humanitarian crises and disasters. The results are intended to inform policy choices across climate mitigation, climate adaptation, disaster risk reduction, sustainable development, and humanitarian assistance.

The Online Data Analytics (ODA) tool is a free and user-friendly platform designed to facilitate the discovery, analysis, and utilization of high-quality data on the views and experiences of Africans. The ODA includes data sets from 39 African countries, with records dating back to 1999. Users can search data sets by country, survey question, or survey round. The tool allows for comparisons between individual countries and regions, as well as providing a continental perspective on selected topics. Data can be filtered by demographic variables such as gender, age, and education level, enabling users to identify trends over time.

The Fragility Forum is a bi-annual event organized by the World Bank Group that brings together practitioners and policymakers from around the world to exchange knowledge and experience on engaging in environments affected by fragility, conflict, and violence.

At the heart of every humanitarian mission lies the critical 3Ws: identifying who is doing what and where. This approach ensures effective coordination, resource allocation, and response by providing a clear overview of the actors involved, their activities, and their locations. The 3W & Connections asset supports humanitarian efforts by mapping these essential elements, enabling organizations to collaborate efficiently and address needs on the ground.

Epidemic Intelligence from Open Sources (EIOS) is a real-time platform developed by the World Health Organization (WHO) and the European Commission to collect, verify, and share public health threat information from open sources. The platform provides a centralized dashboard and alerting system designed to assist health agencies in monitoring emerging epidemics and coordinating responses.

fields.Project/Product Name: Transformative Outcomes: Leveraging Crisis Data in conflict
fields.Project Description: The Transformative Outcomes project deploys an interactive web platform and standardized analysis toolkit to deliver high-quality crisis data for vulnerable populations in conflict-affected settings. This promotes evidence-based planning, targeted interventions, and capacity building among local actors, humanitarian agencies, and policymakers. CRAF’d funding supports data collection in six pilot countries, platform development, and training, catalyzing scalable, accessible data as a global public good.

FNWG Alerts and Early Warning provides timely notifications and early warnings regarding potential risks and emerging threats relevant to the asset. The service delivers clear, concise, and actionable information to support informed decision-making and proactive risk management. All alerts are presented in a neutral and descriptive manner, ensuring that stakeholders receive accurate and objective updates.

KoboToolbox is a free and open-source tool designed for mobile data collection in humanitarian crises. It is utilized by UN agencies, NGOs, and governments, offering features such as offline surveys, real-time dashboards, and collaborative field assessments.

The humanitarian crisis in Nigeria’s northeast states of Borno, Adamawa and Yobe (BAY) continues to severely affect millions of people who remain vulnerable to displacement, impoverishment, and threat of violence. What started as a localized insurgency more than eleven years ago has turned into a regional armed conflict with civilians, mostly women and children bearing the brunt of brutal clashes and attacks.
An open library of global arms production data, featuring company listings, production volumes, and export trends for use in disarmament analysis and policy design.

fields.Project/Product Name: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (JMP)
fields.Project Description: Tracks access to water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) using global indicators and household survey data accessible under open access licenses.
Offers historical data on military spending by country, allowing trend analysis and budget comparisons for global peace research.
This regional platform delivers open-access dashboards, geospatial tools, and statistics to support Pacific states with governance, climate resilience, and disaster response planning.
The Migration Data Portal serves as a unique access point to timely, comprehensive migration statistics and reliable information about migration data on a global scale.

This dataset contains information on countries, commodities, and markets, sourced from the World Food Programme Price Database. Due to the large volume of data, the actual food prices are provided in country-level datasets. The World Food Programme Price Database includes data on foods such as maize, rice, beans, fish, and sugar, covering 98 countries and approximately 3,000 markets. The database is updated weekly, though much of the data is reported on a monthly basis. Historical data is available as far back as 1992 for a few countries, while many others began reporting from 2003 or later.

The database contains information about forcibly displaced populations, compiled from over 70 years of statistical activities. It includes data on various displaced groups such as refugees, asylum-seekers, and internally displaced people, along with their demographic characteristics. The database also covers stateless individuals, most of whom have never experienced displacement. Additionally, it provides information on different solutions for displaced populations, including repatriation and resettlement.

The Global Exposure Database (GED) is a spatial dataset developed by GEM that quantifies the exposure of buildings and infrastructure to natural hazards across countries. It encompasses structural typologies, occupancy data, and geographic distributions, allowing users to estimate potential losses from earthquakes and other disasters. GED is openly available and is widely utilized alongside hazard models to inform national disaster risk management strategies and to support resilience in urban development planning.

Since 1992, the Conflict Barometer has qualitatively and quantitatively recorded the dynamics of political conflicts, both violent and non-violent, worldwide. In accordance with the HIIK methodology, violent conflicts are classified according to their intensity into violent crises (intensity 3), limited wars (intensity 4), and wars (intensity 5). Non-violent conflicts are divided into disputes (intensity 1) and non-violent crises (intensity 2). The annual report is supplemented by conflict maps, graphics, and datasets as well as Spotlight texts that shed light on the wider context of current conflict dynamics.

fields.Project/Product Name: Surveillance System for Attacks on Health Care (SSA)
fields.Project Description: The Surveillance System for Attacks on Health Care (SSA) platform, developed by WHO, collects data on incidents that threaten health care in conflict settings. It provides dashboards and data to support protection analysis.

The Risk Anticipation Data Hub, a project of the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), is a transformative open-access data platform. This comprehensive data warehouse contains over 15,000 indicators, integrating processed and cleaned public datasets that cover a wide range of risk factors. Utilizing advanced technology, including a generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) interface and real-time analytics, the Data Hub provides ecosystem partners with essential data and insights. These resources support improved crisis anticipation, prevention, and response, enabling more informed decision-making and effective action.

This report presents UNHCR’s engagement in multi-sectoral joint needs assessments in 2020, in accordance with Grand Bargain commitments aimed at improving the harmonization and coordination of assessment exercises, as well as increasing transparency for the asset Joint Needs Assessments (JNA).

The Arab Pulse was founded in 2018 to provide an outlet for political discussion on the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) based on quantitative research. The MENA region is in constant flux and faces new and old challenges. The Arab Pulse represents a central nexus for empirical and data-driven research focused on contemporary MENA politics, society, and values, engaging scholars, policymakers, and the media from the region and beyond.

In the face of growing humanitarian challenges, HeiGIT positions geoinformation as a central tool for enhancing crisis response, supporting environmental sustainability, and strengthening community resilience. By leveraging data and digital technologies, it assists humanitarian organizations in identifying vulnerabilities and hazards through risk assessments, integrating local knowledge to ensure context-specific and inclusive solutions. Through its geospatial expertise, HeiGIT pursues faster, smarter, and more effective humanitarian responses.

The data analysis tool enables researchers without access to statistical software packages to perform simple descriptive analyses across all Arab Barometer waves and countries. Results can be downloaded in multiple formats and easily integrated into reports, articles, and presentations.

fields.Project/Product Name: UN Environment Programme World Conservation Monitoring Centre (UNEP-WCMC)
fields.Project Description: UNEP-WCMC is a global science-policy interface that provides open-access datasets and tools on biodiversity, ecosystem services, and conservation strategies. Its data platforms support environmental reporting, climate resilience, and natural capital planning.

Datum is a centralized portal that provides free, open-access databases and RESTful APIs to support disaster risk reduction (DRR) efforts worldwide. All datasets and metadata are available for download or querying under UNDRR’s terms, with the requirement of proper attribution. The portal’s content is organized into several thematic “data clusters,” each of which is versioned and paginated to facilitate easy integration.

To provide decision makers with precise and accurate estimates of population changes and movements, and thereby support interventions in sectors such as health and disaster management, state-of-the-art methods have been developed for estimating population distribution and human mobility using mobile phone usage data, specifically Call Detail Records (CDRs), as well as survey, census, and geospatial data. CDRs are datasets automatically generated by mobile operators for billing purposes, regardless of phone type, and represent an attractive data source for estimating internal migration and displacement, particularly in low- and middle-income countries where data on human mobility are often scarce. These methods enable a more comprehensive understanding of population dynamics, supporting evidence-based decision making in critical sectors.

CLIMADA Platform is an open-source risk assessment tool designed to model economic losses resulting from natural hazards by utilizing hazard, exposure, and vulnerability data. It is intended to support decision-making in policy, research, and risk finance contexts.

EM-DAT compiles free, searchable global records of natural and technological disasters dating back to 1900. It provides standardized event-level data that is extensively used in disaster risk research, policy analysis, and early warning modeling.
The Global Humanitarian Access Overview is ACAPS’ twice-yearly assessment of the barriers that prevent aid from reaching people in crisis and people in crisis from receiving assistance.

To maximise the use of public and private sites and services, such as schools, health facilities, vaccination sites, or mobile money agents, these facilities need to be located where they can reach the largest possible share of the population. Today, detailed data on population distributions, roads and river networks, population mobility patterns, and a range of other geospatial data are available, enabling decision makers to better identify service allocation issues. Using these data, Flowminder has developed a new methodology to support decision makers in identifying optimal locations for their services and to facilitate data-driven decision making.

The Risk Radar is a forward-looking analytical tool developed by ACAPS to identify countries and contexts where the humanitarian situation is likely to deteriorate significantly over the next six months. This tool integrates the monitoring of hundreds of crises, evaluates key drivers and triggers, and applies a systematic risk-analysis methodology—assessing both impact and probability—to highlight areas where urgent attention and preparedness may be required.

fields.Project/Product Name: Cultural Heritage in Crisis Zones Data
fields.Project Description: The List of World Heritage in Danger is intended to inform the international community about conditions that threaten the defining characteristics for which a property was inscribed on the World Heritage List, and to encourage the implementation of corrective actions.

USGS systems offer real-time search and visualization of earthquake data, global hazards, and geophysical datasets. These systems support crisis response and scientific analysis through open APIs. The Earthquakes Maps asset provides users with interactive tools to explore recent seismic activity, access detailed event information, and analyze geophysical trends, facilitating informed decision-making and research.

The UNHCR Statistical Online Population Database provides a comprehensive summary of changes in global trends and levels concerning populations of interest to UNHCR. This includes refugees, asylum-seekers, returned refugees, internally displaced persons (IDPs) protected or assisted by UNHCR, returned IDPs, stateless persons, and other groups of concern. The information is reported by UNHCR country offices and generally reflects data provided by the host country.

INFORM Warning is a state-of-the-art, innovative global risk monitoring tool designed to anticipate complex risks up to a year in advance, directly linked to crisis funding instruments. It transcends traditional methods by presenting multi-hazard information from diverse sources. Its unique analysis offers insights into risk trends, forecasts, scenarios, and potential events leading to crisis impact.

OCHA’s Financial Tracking Service (FTS) collects, standardizes, and publishes real-time humanitarian funding data globally. It provides dashboards and downloadable datasets that track donor and recipient transactions during emergencies, ensuring transparency across funding flows.

GloFAS – Global Flood Awareness System, developed by the European Commission’s Joint Research Centre (EC-JRC) and the European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF), provides open-access flood forecasts and risk assessments. It integrates global hydrological models to support early warning systems and flood preparedness planning.

Developed by the Global Earthquake Model (GEM) Foundation, the OpenQuake Platform is an open-source tool for seismic hazard and risk assessment. It provides researchers, engineers, and governments with models, tools, and databases to simulate earthquake impacts, assess vulnerability, and inform urban planning and disaster preparedness strategies. OpenQuake integrates data on seismicity, exposure, and building fragility, and is widely used in both academic research and national risk management initiatives.

ADAPT assists governments in assessing their statistical capacity, planning national data strategies, and making cost-effective investments in data infrastructure. It supports Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) tracking and capacity development in low- and middle-income countries.
HXL is a simple standard designed for messy data. It uses HXL hashtags to accelerate data processing and enable interoperability across various data sources.

fields.Project/Product Name: Guidelines for National Strategy for the Development of Statistics (NSDS)
fields.Project Description: The Guidelines for National Strategy for the Development of Statistics (NSDS) by PARIS21 provide structured guidance and tools to assist countries in designing national statistics strategies, aligning donor support, and integrating data systems for sustainable development planning.
The Conflict Data Dashboard presents all recorded security incidents by date, location, type, perpetrator, and the impact on civilians.

The IPC Analytics Portal serves as the global public platform where official IPC food insecurity analyses and maps are published. It provides a single-entry point for accessing validated IPC classifications from around the world.

The Data Futures Exchange is an open-source platform designed to serve as a central hub for data innovation, with a particular emphasis on development impact. The platform is aligned with the thematic priorities of the United Nations Development Programme and utilizes a systemic approach combined with advanced analytics to identify actions that accelerate sustainable development on a global scale.

PDC’s advanced natural language processing and generative AI are being leveraged to greatly reduce the manual labor and time involved with finding, analyzing, and curating global hazard content. This enables PDC to provide more comprehensive coverage of hazard events worldwide through its DisasterAWARE Pro risk intelligence and early warning platform. These repetitive and time-consuming tasks are now performed by AI Hazard Finder with greater speed and accuracy than previously possible.

The Malaria Indicator Surveys (MIS) collect data on household ownership and use of mosquito nets, malaria prevention during pregnancy, and access to effective treatment for fever in children. These surveys often include biomarker testing for malaria and anemia, enabling countries to assess progress toward malaria control targets.

fields.Project/Product Name: GRID3: Geo-Referenced Infrastructure and Demographic Data for Development
fields.Project Description: GRID3 provides high-resolution geospatial data, including population estimates, infrastructure mapping, and administrative boundaries, to support governments and organizations in planning, monitoring, and delivering services effectively.

The World Population Dashboard presents comprehensive global population data, including statistics on fertility rates, gender parity in school enrolment, and information related to sexual and reproductive health, among other key indicators. These data collectively provide insight into the health and rights of populations worldwide, with a particular focus on women and young people. The figures are sourced from UNFPA and other United Nations agencies, and are updated on an annual basis.
The HeRAMS Initiative aims to ensure that core information on essential health resources and services is readily available to decision makers at country, regional, and global levels.

Driven by regularly collected primary data, the objective of the Data in Emergencies (DIEM) Hub is to understand the impact of shocks in food crisis contexts and to inform decision-making in support of agricultural livelihoods. The DIEM Hub has been publicly available since June 2021.

The Global Crisis Response Platform (GCRP) is a data and analytics platform that aggregates global risk indicators, country profiles, and dashboards to support early-warning, crisis preparedness, and financing decisions across development and humanitarian systems.
This database tracks country participation in UN and regional peace operations, including details on troop numbers, funding, and deployment dates.

The Humanitarian Data Forum provides an opportunity for members of the data community to reconnect and collaborate. The inaugural Forum, held in The Hague, brought together over 160 participants from 42 countries to help shape the future of humanitarian data. Attendees represented a diverse range of organizations, including UN agencies, local and global NGOs, governments, the private sector, and academia.
MAP provides high-resolution maps of malaria risk and stability, combining epidemiological and environmental data to support global health planning, investment, and disease modeling.
The Famine Action Mechanism (FAM) is a global partnership dedicated to scaling up anticipatory and early action to protect lives and livelihoods from emerging food security crises.

Since the end of World War II, the practice of peace mediation was restricted to diplomatic circles and international organizations, such as the United Nations. In recent decades, however, the field has witnessed the emergence of a new group of non-governmental actors known as Peace Facilitation Organizations (PFOs). PFOs are defined as independent organizations whose work consists of facilitating, advising, supporting, or implementing peace mediation or dialogue initiatives. The PFOs mapping dataset documents the PFOs that currently operate worldwide and provides information on their background, structure, approach, modus operandi, funding model, and other characteristics. The mapping aims to shed light on this field and identify these organizations, primarily from Western countries, that have professionalized peace mediation and contributed a certain degree of dexterity and standardization to peace processes.

The Global Crisis Risk Platform (GCRP) is an integrated analytics platform designed to assess and anticipate multidimensional crisis risks. It provides open-access dashboards, country risk profiles, and composite indicators to support anticipatory action and inform crisis financing decisions.

The Global Seismic Hazard Map (GSHM), developed under the auspices of the Global Earthquake Model (GEM), provides probabilistic assessments of earthquake hazards worldwide. It combines global seismicity data, geological models, and ground motion prediction equations to estimate the likelihood of earthquake-induced ground shaking. The GSHM supports disaster risk reduction, urban planning, and insurance risk modeling by offering a harmonized and peer-reviewed reference for national and regional seismic hazard assessments.

ACLED Trendfinder offers an array of interconnected tools for tracking patterns of political violence and protest. Using the visualization platform, users can identify important changes in political violence and protest across and within countries, situate this activity within historical contexts, and spot early warning signs.
The approach focuses on optimizing data collection, analysis, and dissemination of information to enable transparent communication and cooperation between stakeholders.

The 510 Data Team supports innovation by implementing data science projects focused on disaster preparedness, local early warning systems, and the development of big data tools throughout the Red Cross network.

The Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) provide comprehensive and nationally representative data for monitoring and evaluating population, health, and nutrition indicators. These surveys support evidence-based decision-making and program design in developing countries by collecting high-quality information on fertility, family planning, maternal and child health, and HIV/AIDS.

The World Health Organization (WHO) Health Emergency Dashboard is a platform designed to share information about public health events and emergencies. The data on the dashboard is refreshed every thirty (30) minutes, and the information is accurate as of the time of the latest update.

The Data Catalog is designed to make World Bank’s development data easy to find, download, use, and share. It includes data from the World Bank’s microdata, finances, and energy data platforms, as well as datasets from the open data catalog. There are different ways to access and download datasets.

FAO’s AQUASTAT is a global water information system that provides open-access data on water availability, irrigation, and usage. It supports analysis and decision-making related to food security, hydrology, and agricultural planning.
UCDP offers conflict datasets, battle event data, and fatalities statistics to support academic and policy research on global violence trends.

fields.Project/Product Name: Stockholm Forum on Peace and Development
fields.Project Description: Held annually, the Stockholm Forum on Peace and Development is a dialogue-driven event that offers a neutral platform for interdisciplinary exchange among members of international communities working in development, humanitarian, peacebuilding, and security sectors. The event is recognized for its discussion-led roundtable sessions, which are developed in collaboration with partner organizations and encourage active participation from stakeholders at all levels.

The INFORM Risk Index is a multi-hazard risk assessment tool developed by the Inter-Agency Standing Committee (IASC) and the European Commission. It combines data on hazards, vulnerability, and coping capacity to produce a composite score of disaster risk in over 190 countries. The index supports evidence-based disaster preparedness, humanitarian planning, and crisis response by identifying countries most at risk of crises that could overwhelm national response capacities. It is updated annually and incorporates more than 50 indicators.

Monitoring and evaluation (M&E) activities are supported as fundamental components for understanding impact, ensuring transparency, and fostering continuous improvements to projects. The objective is to deliver customized, robust frameworks and methodologies specifically designed to capture the outcomes of partners’ initiatives. The most effective M&E processes are considered to be continuous and should be integrated throughout the project wherever feasible. This approach ensures ongoing tracking of progress and transparently communicates the impact of the project to both donors and the communities being supported.

HHI Conferences is an academic and applied research center dedicated to advancing humanitarian response through evidence-based practice, data science, and technology. The center serves as a bridge between academia, practitioners, and policy stakeholders.

A first-of-its-kind global dataset on women’s roles
in non-state armed groups is set to enhance peacebuilding across 500 women’s wings of non-state
armed groups. Led by the University of Denver in
collaboration with research partners, the project will
inform programming in conflict-affected settings.

Provides harmonized survey data covering public opinion on governance, religion, and economics in more than 20 Arab countries. The data is freely accessible and supports comparative analysis across the region.

IPUMS provides harmonized, high-quality census and survey data from over 100 countries. Available through an open-access platform, its datasets enable global research on health, population trends, labor, and development outcomes.

PDC’s Multi-hazard Risk Score combines multi-hazard exposure, vulnerability (susceptibility to impact), and coping capacity (the relative ability to absorb negative disaster impacts). This score provides a comprehensive measure of how each country may be affected by hazards and disasters as a whole over time.
The Conflict Monitors cover key areas and are designed to support conflict analysis, violence-prevention initiatives, and efforts to monitor emerging crisis situations.

fields.Project/Product Name: World Bank-UNHCR Joint Data Center on Forced Displacement
fields.Project Description: The World Bank-UNHCR Joint Data Center on Forced Displacement (JDC) is a joint initiative dedicated to improving the collection, analysis, and use of data on forcibly displaced populations. The JDC provides public goods such as surveys, microdata, and research, all focused on informing development and humanitarian action through evidence-based approaches.

The ROOTS Portal provides a comprehensive dataset on local organizations, featuring a 3W map (Who does What, Where) that outlines the operational presence of both national and international organizations. This platform enables users to access detailed information about the activities and locations of various organizations, supporting coordination and informed decision-making.

Managed by the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA), the Humanitarian Data Exchange (HDX) is a centralized platform for sharing humanitarian data. It offers access to over 20,000 datasets from more than 300 organizations, covering themes such as population, conflict, health, and displacement. HDX includes the Data Grid and the COVID-19 Data Explorer, and it plays a crucial role in promoting data transparency, interoperability, and informed decision-making in humanitarian settings.

UN Women’s strategy for change, Women Count, seeks to bring about a radical shift in how gender statistics are used, created, and promoted. The initiative aims to transform the landscape of gender data by improving the production, accessibility, and utilization of gender statistics. Women Count works to ensure that reliable and comprehensive gender data informs policies, programs, and decision-making processes, ultimately advancing gender equality and empowering women and girls globally.

The global Multidimensional Poverty Index (global MPI) is an annual international measure of acute multidimensional poverty that covers over 100 developing countries. It complements traditional monetary poverty measures by capturing the acute, overlapping deprivations in health, education, and living standards that people in poverty experience. The global MPI is computed by the Oxford Poverty and Human Development Initiative (OPHI) in partnership with the Human Development Report Office of the United Nations Development Programme.

The iMMAP Inc. global surge team consists of over 400 highly qualified and diverse national and international technical information management (IM) specialists. When required, iMMAP Inc. deploys experts on mission who combine technical IM skills with sectoral and programmatic experience in areas such as Coordination, Food Security, Health, Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH), Protection, Nutrition, Cash, market and value chain analysis, context and geopolitical analysis, assessments, research, and more. These deployments are designed to improve country, regional, and global decision-making and planning processes in alignment with the Humanitarian Programme Cycle (HPC) principles.

The initial scope of HDX HAPI was aligned with that of the HDX Data Grids, focusing on providing the foundational data required to understand humanitarian contexts. Over time, the scope of HDX HAPI has expanded beyond the original Data Grids to encompass a broader range of data. A live dashboard is available to monitor data availability by country.

Learn the basics and progress to becoming an advanced user in DisasterAWARE software. On-site, instructor-led classroom training is available at either the client’s location or the provider’s facilities. Support is offered to help achieve nearly any training objective.

The Operational Data Portal (ODP) enables UNHCR to fulfill its institutional responsibility by providing an information and data sharing platform that facilitates coordination during refugee emergencies. This is accomplished through the use of independent ‘situation views’ that cover major emergencies, such as the Syria situation and the Central African Republic emergency, among others, ensuring comprehensive and accessible data management for effective humanitarian response.

IDMC conducts annual severity assessments to compare the living conditions of internally displaced households with those of returnee and non-displaced households within the same country. These assessments evaluate access to adequate housing, stable income, food security, and education, as well as the level of fear related to exposure to conflict or violence, explosive hazards, and other threats.

The Aid Worker Security Database (AWSD) records major incidents of violence against aid workers, with incident reports spanning from 1997 to the present. Initiated in 2005, the AWSD remains the sole comprehensive global source of these data, providing the evidence base for analysis of the changing security environment for civilian aid operations.

UNICEF is recognized as the world’s leading source of data on children and maintains databases containing hundreds of internationally valid and comparable indicators. With this extensive wealth of information, the UNICEF Data Warehouse is designed to provide easy access to these indicators across a wide range of countries, with some datasets extending back several decades.

fields.Project/Product Name: GIEWS - Global Information and Early Warning System on Food and Agriculture
fields.Project Description: FAO’s GIEWS delivers near real-time crop and food supply monitoring, offering geospatial visualizations and drought alerts across over 100 countries. The data supports food security risk assessment and response planning.
An archive of anonymized survey and refugee data available under open-access licenses, supporting demographic and displacement research across global contexts.

fields.Project/Product Name: United Nations Report on Military Expenditures (UNMilEx)
fields.Project Description: UNODA publishes annual data on military spending from Member States, informing arms control and global transparency through structured datasets.

fields.Project/Product Name: EMPOW: Women’s Empowerment in Peace Processes
fields.Project Description: EMPOW will address the data gap on Women, Peace and Security (WPS) by creating interoperable datasets: EMPOW Agency and EMPOW Reform. The objective is to generate and harmonize data on women's empowerment across all peace process phases—from pre-negotiations to post-war peacebuilding—and ensure compatibility with leading crisis data, such as the Uppsala Conflict Data Program.

PeaceRep distributes the PA-X Tracker, an innovative digital tool designed to provide data-driven insights that support peace and transition processes. The suite of PeaceTech tools within the PA-X Tracker enables users to track and monitor the progress and implementation of peace and transition initiatives. The Tracker offers a comprehensive understanding of how peace processes are unfolding, identifies the stakeholders involved, and assesses the impact of these processes across a range of institutional, political, economic, humanitarian, and security indicators.

Developed by the International Crisis Group, EEARTH is a revolutionary early warning system designed to identify climate-driven conflict pathways in the Horn of Africa. By integrating both quantitative and qualitative data, it offers a comprehensive approach to climate-security risks. Initially piloted in Somalia and South Sudan, EEARTH provides insights into the underlying causes of conflict risks. Its innovative approach is geared towards anticipating, preventing, and addressing the repercussions of climate-related security threats.

fields.Project/Product Name: Early Warning, Alert and Response System (EWARS)
fields.Project Description: The Early Warning, Alert and Response System (EWARS) provides real-time monitoring of epidemic outbreaks. It supports crisis response planning and risk assessment through the use of online reporting platforms and dashboards.

Trigger models are employed to establish danger levels that activate humanitarian anticipatory Early Action Protocols (EAPs). These models are developed using the Impact-Based Forecasting (IBF) methodology. Models have been built to trigger EAPs for hazards such as typhoon, flood, dzud, drought, and dengue.

The Latinobarómetro Online Analysis Platform enables users to explore and analyze data directly in their browser, without the need to download files or register. The platform is powered by JDSurvey, an analysis tool developed by JD Systems (Madrid), which is also responsible for maintaining the Latinobarómetro Data Archive.

The Key Indicators Survey (KIS) is designed to address the monitoring and evaluation needs of programs engaged in population and health activities in developing countries. It is particularly useful for generating data for small areas, such as regions, districts, or catchment areas, which may be the focus of individual projects. However, the KIS can also be applied in nationally representative surveys. The KIS tool comprises questionnaires, interviewer’s manuals, sampling guidelines, and a tabulation plan.

The WFP Innovation Forum is a global platform that showcases groundbreaking solutions to address food insecurity and humanitarian challenges. Bringing together innovators, humanitarian actors, private sector leaders, and policymakers, the forum highlights cutting-edge technologies, from AI-powered disaster response to sustainable agriculture, that are transforming the way hunger and crises are tackled around the world.

HERA supports NGOs in their development by assisting with the creation of strategic frameworks, annual action plans, exploratory missions, project evaluations, security package implementation, and risk assessments. This comprehensive support enables organizations to enhance their effectiveness and achieve their goals.

Embracing a grassroots ethos, the team forges vital connections on the frontline. Before initiating data collection, they thoroughly explore the digital landscape to identify existing efforts and avoid redundancy. These online insights are then integrated with raw field data, gathered through collaboration with trusted local partners.
An analytical platform that tracks country-level data system development and SDG readiness, providing dashboards and indicators to support the alignment of donor assistance with national priorities.

The Global Internal Displacement Database (GIDD) is the result of an annual process that includes the collection, harmonization, and validation of data, followed by a comprehensive peer review. The process involves engagement with primary data providers and relevant stakeholders at national, regional, and global levels. Published each year, the GIDD has been recognized in several United Nations resolutions for its importance. The database provides detailed data by country and year for conflict-induced displacement, while disaster-induced displacement is documented at the event level. Since 2023, additional disaggregated data has also been made available.
Provides publicly available datasets on the legal transfers of major conventional weapons between countries. The database is widely used in security and disarmament monitoring.

IDMC’s Global Report on Internal Displacement (GRID) is the authoritative source for data and analysis on the state of internal displacement for the previous year. Each year, IDMC presents validated estimates of internal displacements caused by conflict and disasters, as well as the total cumulative numbers of internally displaced persons (IDPs) worldwide. The GRID also provides an overview of the year’s most significant internal displacement situations, highlighting potential measures to address the issue across the humanitarian, development, disaster risk reduction, and climate change agendas.

UNHCR’s case management and registration system manages refugee and asylum-seeker data. The platform supports operational planning, registration, and data interoperability across protection and assistance programs.

This is a global platform that tracks investments in national statistical systems. It offers open-access monitoring of resource flows, donor commitments, and financing gaps related to data for development.

The goal is to empower and equip organizations with the knowledge, skill sets, and tools necessary to overcome challenges, enabling them to respond more effectively in the present and sustain success in the future. Both in-person and remote learning environments are created to foster continuous improvement and innovation, ensuring that partners consistently grow and adapt to change.

PHASI® is a data integration and analysis platform developed by the American Red Cross that aggregates multi-sectoral indicators to identify public health and safety risks. It supports disaster planning, resource allocation, and early warning efforts.

fields.Project/Product Name: Enhancing Early Warning Systems for Disaster Risk Reduction (E4DRR)
fields.Project Description: ICPAC and NORCAP are building hazard models, impact estimates, and climate storylines for drought and flood events in Eastern Africa. Using ensemble prediction systems, the project creates counterfactual, physically consistent event narratives and composite datasets to improve impact-based forecasting, anticipatory action, and loss-damage assessment. Integrated into the East Africa Hazard Watch Portal, this work fills data gaps, strengthens localized risk insights, and supports more effective disaster risk reduction across a region facing climate, conflict, and displacement pressures.

RAIS is a digital system designed for monitoring and coordinating assistance in refugee operations. It supports operations by registering aid delivery and tracking service provision across various displacement contexts.

fields.Project/Product Name: SIPRI Mapping ATT-Relevant Cooperation and Assistance Activities Database
fields.Project Description: Tracks international arms transfer assistance and cooperation initiatives. It supports transparency and reporting under the Arms Trade Treaty through searchable data.

The Microdata Library is a collection of datasets from the World Bank and other international, regional, and national organizations. The World Bank’s Microdata Library facilitates access to microdata collected through sample surveys of households, business establishments, or other facilities. These microdata provide information about people living in developing countries, their institutions, their environment, their communities, and the operation of their economies. Many of these datasets are available as open data; users should check the terms of use associated with each dataset.
A centralized data library that offers curated conflict-related datasets, published by the UN Department of Peace Operations (DPO), to support analytic peace and security programming.

fields.Project/Product Name: SWOT: The Safe Water Optimization Tool
Population Registration and Identity Management EcoSystem (PRIMES)
fields.Project Description:
At the center of UNHCR’s work with registration and identity management is PRIMES, the digital Population Registration and Identity Management Ecosystem developed by UNHCR. PRIMES integrates all of UNHCR’s digital registration, identity management, and case management tools into a single, internally connected and interoperable ecosystem.

PRIMES consists of several repositories for personal data, including both biographic and biometric information, as well as supporting data. It incorporates multiple tools that securely utilize this information to deliver targeted protection, assistance, and solutions to refugees and other displaced populations. PRIMES enables a range of functions, including:

- Identity management, encompassing registration, biometric enrolment, and documentation
- Case management, covering key protection aspects such as Refugee Status Determination, Resettlement, Statelessness, Repatriation, Legal and Physical Protection, Child Protection, Sexual and Gender-Based Violence (SGBV), and others
- Assistance, including both cash and in-kind support
- Data management, which includes reporting and analysis to support evidence-informed action for quality protection outcomes

PRIMES is designed with cooperation and interoperability as core principles, allowing governments and partners supporting refugees to utilize the data and technology developed by UNHCR. This enhances their capacity to deliver services, often in collaboration with UNHCR, in a safe and secure manner. PRIMES is fully aligned with the Policy on the Protection of Personal Data of Persons of Concern to UNHCR.

The Conflict Exposure Calculator integrates data from ACLED with population size estimates from WorldPop to estimate the civilian impact based on proximity to an event, event type, type of violent actor or specific armed group, location, and time.

The SIPRI National Budget Archive provides government spending data from multiple countries, facilitating transparent comparisons of military and civilian budget priorities. This resource supports analysis related to disarmament and peacebuilding by offering comprehensive and accessible budget information.

Developed by the DPPA’s Innovation Cell in collaboration with academic partners, Geoguard is the first-ever geospatial dashboard designed for decision-makers seeking insight on environmental and conflict risks across the Middle East, Central, and West Africa. Utilizing cutting-edge technology, Geoguard aggregates millions of data points on environmental conditions and geo-coded conflict events into an intuitive dashboard, drawing from diverse data sources as well as locally collected or crowd-sourced information. The platform provides immediate insight into environmental risk factors throughout specified regions and offers snapshots in time that are linked to trends in conflict and social unrest.

Strategy & Systems Development offers a comprehensive suite of services designed to ensure that work is targeted and effective. These services enable organizations to plan strategically, implement operations efficiently, and adapt proactively to dynamic and evolving situations. The primary objective is to establish efficient systems that optimize operations, empowering partners to work smarter rather than harder. This approach encompasses the development and integration of technology to enhance efficiency, scalability, and communication. By streamlining processes, operational costs are reduced and a foundation is laid for sustainable impact.

fields.Project/Product Name: Humanitarian Data Science and Ethics Group (DSEG)
fields.Project Description: The Humanitarian Data Science and Ethics Group (DSEG) is a community of practice dedicated to advancing ethical, responsible, and inclusive data science within humanitarian contexts. The group supports the development and implementation of standards, tools, and guidance that prioritize protection principles and data accountability.
iMMAP delivers assessment tools, training, and data services to support MSNA-led humanitarian coordination across emergencies, streamlining data aggregation across sectors.

Conflict Forecast specializes in conflict forecasting, prevention, and decision support. The forecasting methodology is explicitly designed to detect new, subtle signals of conflict risk in countries not currently at war. Detecting these risks is extremely difficult and requires accepting false positives. These predictions are then integrated into a novel policy evaluation tool to assess the tradeoff between the benefits of preventive action and the costs of acting on false-positive signals.

The 2024 Socio-Economic Insights Survey (SEIS) in Estonia provides a comprehensive assessment of the needs and vulnerabilities of refugees from Ukraine. Conducted as part of an annual interagency regional process led by UNHCR, this assessment supports the Regional Refugee Response Plan (RRP) for the Ukraine Situation. Covering topics such as protection, health, education, shelter, livelihoods, and food security, the survey offers critical data to inform evidence-based planning and prioritization, ensuring the specific needs of different refugee groups are addressed. Data collection was conducted through face-to-face interviews from May to July 2024 with a probability-based random sample of refugee households, managed collaboratively by UNHCR and the International Organization for Migration. Findings will guide strategic interventions and resource allocation to enhance the welfare and resilience of the refugee population in Estonia.

UNESCO’s platform delivers open access data on emergency-affected education systems, including enrollment figures, disruptions, and inclusion metrics. This resource supports global response planning in crises and displacement settings by providing comprehensive and reliable information on the state of education in emergencies.

CLIFDEW-GRID, developed by UNHCR in collaboration with the University of California Irvine, is an ambitious initiative dedicated to addressing the complex challenge of climate-induced forced displacement, including through the creation of the first risk index of its kind. This project leverages advanced data analytics and innovative methodologies to enable CRAF’d ecosystem partners to anticipate and respond effectively to the escalating crisis of climate-induced displacement. By providing forecasts at a subnational level, CLIFDEW-GRID offers a more nuanced understanding of in-country heterogeneity compared to traditional country-level approaches. The system will be piloted in selected countries in Western and Eastern Africa.

CLIFDEW-GRID functions as an early warning, grid-based modeling system designed to predict potential climate-induced forced displacement. It is a joint, innovative data project led by UNHCR and the University of California Irvine, with financial support from the Complex Risk Analytics Fund (CRAF’d).

The INFORM Risk Index is a multi-hazard risk assessment tool developed by the Inter-Agency Standing Committee (IASC) and the European Commission. It combines data on hazards, vulnerability, and coping capacity to produce a composite score of disaster risk in over 190 countries. The index supports evidence-based disaster preparedness, humanitarian planning, and crisis response by identifying countries most at risk of crises that could overwhelm national response capacities. It is updated annually and incorporates more than 50 indicators.

ASR monitors the demographic and socioeconomic profiles of refugee populations worldwide. Its standardized surveys and data visualizations support evidence-based protection, education, and livelihood programming.

The Multi-Sectoral Needs Assessment (MSNA) is a standardized, country-level data collection initiative designed to capture multi-sectoral needs among crisis-affected populations. The data collected through this assessment informs strategic planning, prioritization, and humanitarian response efforts.

fields.Project/Product Name: NYU + VIEWS: Data for Peace Conference

fields.Project Description: LearnOSM offers clear, easy-to-understand, step-by-step guides designed to help users get started with contributing to OpenStreetMap and utilizing OpenStreetMap data. For those interested in organizing an OpenStreetMap workshop, LearnOSM also provides comprehensive trainer resources.

HDX Signals is a product and service provided by the Humanitarian Data Exchange (HDX) that monitors key datasets and generates automated notifications via email when significant, negative changes are detected. The system is designed to support timely decision-making by alerting users to important shifts in humanitarian data.

WorldPop is an interdisciplinary applied research group that focuses on supporting the improvement of the spatial demographic evidence base and the use of these data for health and development applications, including addressing the Sustainable Development Goals. The group’s mission is to enable decision makers to harness the power of spatial demographic data through high quality applied research, with the vision of a world where everyone, everywhere is counted in decision making.
